dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO MARCH, our heroine, hesitates. In the half-light of a dim hallway, she exhales and prepa her head bowed like a boxer about to go into the ring. Sh puts her hand on the doorknob. A pause, and then, she ope it onto a disorderly room. It is full of men. Some sit with their feet up on the des higher than their hats, which they do not remove for her. They smoke and read, hardly noticing that she has walked Jo walks through the desks, looking for one in particular

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (clearing her throat) Excuse me. MR. DASHWOOD (the oldest, smokiest gentleman) looks at he

dialogues.speaker: JO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was looking for the Weekly Volcano office... I wished to see Mr. Dashwood? Mr. Dashwood stares silently.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nervous, presenting pages) A friend of mine desired me to offer a story, by her, she wrote it - she’d be glad to write more if this suits. He stands and extends his rough, large hand. She gives hi the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: (turning the pages over) Not a first attempt, I take it?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No, sir; she has sold to “Olympic” and “Scandal” and got a prize for a tale in the “Blarney Stone Banner.”

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: A prize?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (weakly) Yes.  He now takes in Jo’s appearance and her mended clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Sit. Jo sits, hands folded, trying to cover the ink stains. Mr Dashwood reads her story with a pen in hand, gleefully crossing out and making notes, changes. Every time his pe scratches, Jo feels her heart breaking. She’s on the verg tears when:

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll take this.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (looking up) You will?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: With alterations. It’s too long. She nods and he hands it back to her, page after page wit her work crossed out. She examines it.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You’ve cut - I took care to have a few of my sinners repent.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: The country just went through a war. People want to be amused, not preached at. Morals don’t sell nowadays. (pointedly) Perhaps mention that to your “friend.” Jo looks again at her completely altered story.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What do you - that is, what compensation —

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: We pay twenty-five to thirty for things of this sort. We’ll pay twenty for that.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (money over art) You can have it. Make the edits. Jo hands over the story, Mr. Dashwood hands over the mone business done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (then) Should I tell my, my friend that you'll take another if she had one better than this?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: We'll look at it. Tell her to make it short and spicy. And if the main character’s a girl make sure she’s married by the end. (casually) Or dead, either way.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Excuse me? But he’s on to the next bit of business.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: What name would she like put to the story?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh, yes - none at all if you please. He considers her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Just as she likes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. Good day. EXT. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1868. The streets of New York. After the Civil War and at the b of The Industrial Revolution. It is a city in the middle becoming, the 20th century on the horizon. Horses, trolle young, old, black, white, immigrants, returning soldiers, factory workers, wealthy industrialists, fashionable wome and poor mothers all crowd the streets. We find Jo (also becoming) sprinting down the street with utter joy. She has pulled up her skirts and is running fu steam. Not lady-running, flat-out RUNNING. For the joy of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo reading and walking at the same time, bounding two-at- time up the steps of a large brownstone boarding house. S stoops to pick up a cat who suns herself on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (to the cat) My Beth would like you very much. As Jo walks through the house, into the drawing room, she lets the cat down, and goes straight to the fireplace. Sh stands with her back to it, to warm herself, and produces small notebook and begins to write. She is so engrossed with her writing that she doesn’t hea the boisterous group of college students and professors, and a few women, when they descend upon the room. She jus keeps writing, until:

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Miss March. Jo looks up from her notebook to see FRIEDRICH BHAER look down at her. He speaks with a French accent, and, like al Europeans, seems to know something that we Americans don’

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (she straightens up) Good afternoon, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: You're on fire.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: (suddenly animated) You're on fire! Jo suddenly notices that the back of her dress has caught fire. In a panic, another woman of the group helps her an the dress is put out. Disaster is avoided, although not humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: (laughing) I have the same habit, you see?  5. He shows her scorch marks on his jacket. Jo is about to l when, MRS. KIRKE, the landlady, bustles into the room:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRKE
dialogues.text: Kitty and Minny are waiting! Jo looks up the stairs to see the two little girls pranci

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: My students need me.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: Always working.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (joke-dramatically) Money is the end and aim of my mercenary existence.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: No one gets ink stains like yours just out of a desire for money. Jo feels the intense pleasure and pain of being seen by someone, of knowing that they know you.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, retreating) Well my sister Amy is in Paris, and until she marries someone obscenely wealthy, it’s up to me to keep the family afloat. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: (staring up after her) Goodbye. EXT. FRANCE. PARIS. DAY. 1868. AMY MARCH, an angelic 20-year-old with golden curls, is painting a staged scene, along with a few other young artists. It is a classic scene of two young men and a you woman at a picnic, and Amy is rendering it realistically, imitating the 18th & 19th century painters she loved. She looks at the painting of the young man next to her. H doing something radically different - the paint is obviou the colors are bright and un-life-like, space is flattene It is not meant to be realistic: it is the beginning of modernism. She looks back at her own piece and realizes that she mig have missed the moment that she came here to master.  6. Perhaps she’s already passed before her time. She continu working, troubled. EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868. Amy rides in an open air carriage with AUNT MARCH, readin letter from home. Everyone in Paris is out. Aunt March is only happy when she’s complaining, and she’s in excellent form this morning. It is the place to see and be seen and March is doing both excellently.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: The decadents have ruined Paris, if you ask me. These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush. No response from Amy.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: AMY! I said, “These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush.”

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh yes! Very true, Aunt March.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Don’t humor me, girl. What do they write, your troublemaking family?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Mother doesn’t say anything about Beth. I feel I should go back but they all say “stay.”

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: You can do nothing if you go back. The girl is sick, not lonely. Amy gives her a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you shouldn't go home until you and Fred Vaughn are properly engaged. Amy blushes and puts the letter away.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Yes, and until I’ve completed all of my painting lessons, of course. Aunt March looks at her, momentarily confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oh, yes, yes. Of course. Amy looks at all the passers-by. She sees a somber young tall and dark and looking down as he walks. Suddenly!

dialogues.speaker: STOP THE CARRIAGE
dialogues.text: Abandoning her primness, she launches out of the carriage runs, nearly knocking people over. This is Theodore Laure LAURIE, a 26-year-old without a sense of direction, like 26-year-olds. They hug joyously and un-self-consciously:

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE AMY
dialogues.text: AMY! You're so /grown up! /You wrote you'd come to the hotel!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE AMY
dialogues.text: I looked for you and couldn’t /You didn’t look hard enoug find /you anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE AMY
dialogues.text: Maybe I just didn’t recognize (making a face) you, you’ve become so /Please don’t. beaut/iful.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I thought you liked that sort of thing!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: NO. Where’s your Grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE AMY
dialogues.text: Still in Germany. I’m on my (teasing him) own, traveling and /having /and drinking and gambling fun. and flirting...

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell your mother!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Are you chasing some young girl across Europe?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (darkening) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping her playfulness) I’m... I couldn’t believe Jo turned you down. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (crisp) Don’t be, Amy. I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (to Laurie) Oh, Aunt March! Laurie gallops over, and jumps into the carriage, kissing her:

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Aren’t we fine, /Ma’am. /GET HIM OFF OF ME! He kisses her again, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Il faut GO! Allons-y! Aunt March attempts to get the carriage to leave, and Lau is thrown off while Amy is thrown in.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (calling after Laurie) Come to the New Year’s Party! It’s a ball and everyone will be there, including Fred - Pick me up at the hotel at eight - the Chavain! Dress for festivities! Top hats and silks!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I will! I’11 wear my best silk! Laurie turns and continues his heartbroken stroll, as Amy looks at him. She turns back to Aunt March.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It’s Laurie!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: I know. Amy turns around to get one last look at Laurie. She love him, as she’s always loved him.  INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868. MEG MARCH, beautiful but with the melancholy of yearning emanating from her, is browsing the silks with Sallie Mof a rich young woman who possesses an air of casual boredom that comes from never having to work for what you have.

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE
dialogues.text: (to the clerk) Twenty yards of the blue silk as well as the pink. Someone will be by for it later. She looks over at Meg, who touches a beautiful grey silk:

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Meg! That would look so lovely on you. I know just the dressmaker to send you to. You'll be the prettiest wife in Concord.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Oh no, John needs a new coat for winter and Daisy and Demi need new clothes and --

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE
dialogues.text: -- and his wife needs a new dress.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (trying to hide her embarrassment) I can’t... it’s, I just can’t.

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE
dialogues.text: He'll be so pleased with how you look that he’1ll forget all about the expense.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (equivocating) I don’t suppose it’s such an extravagance.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Will twenty yards do?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (deciding) Yes. Thank you. And Meg watches, delighted but fighting guilt, as the beautiful fabric is cut.  10. EXT. MEG MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1868. From inside a modest rural cottage, Meg emerges, wiping h hands and muttering to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (ashamed) Fifty dollars, what was I thinking? She sees her two 3-year-olds, a boy and a girl, DAISY and DEMI, playing in the yard. She sits down to watch them, feeling both grateful and trapped. They run up to her.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY AND DEMI
dialogues.text: Mommy -- mommy! They fall into her arms, she accepts them and then sends off to play again. We hear sounds a beautiful Bach piano sonata being played... EXT. / INT. MARCH HOUSE. 1868. «+. the music grows louder as we see empty rooms of the childhood home -- the attic, the dining room, the stairs. Finally we find BETH MARCH, alone at the piano. She stops playing suddenly, as if in pain. Then she takes a deep breath, feels the sunlight on her hand, and stretches it

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Beth! Beth? She doesn’t respond. INT. NEW YORK THEATRE. EVENING. 1868. Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night unfolds on stage. Jo is in th back, the cheap standing-room. She’s so wrapped up that s moves in until she’s practically leaning over the railing It’s the scene where Viola (dressed as a man) seduces Oli

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: .+-That you do think you are not what you are.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLA
dialogues.text: Then think you right, I am not what I am! Friedrich watches the play from his own, proper, seat. At certain point, he sees Jo, and then watches her watching play, her delight making him smile.  11. INT. NEW YORK THEATRE LOBBY. NIGHT. 1868. The audience flows out of the theatre into the lobby. Jo, still in her theatrical reverie, spots Friedrich. She freezes, not moving, not wanting to be seen. She then follows behind the band of friends, drawn to the spite of herself. INT. GERMAN BEER HALL. NIGHT. 1868. It is a rowdy and raucous crowd, drinking and dancing. Jo walks through the crowd, taking it in, watching Friedrich knows everyone and can speak half a dozen languages. Anot man young, speaking a language Jo doesn’t know, offers hi hand for the dance.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I only speak English...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Come dance! He pulls her into the dance, and she does her best to fol along. It’s whirling and loud and wild. Before long, she finds herself paired with Friedrich and all self- consciousness leaves her. She is part of the night and th room and the music and she throws herself into movement, we are taken back to.... THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 186 ...the sisters, all together again in the past, in the sn globe of girlhood and memory that is ever present but for gone, are in a flurry of getting ready for a holiday part

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I know just who I’1l1 dance with!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Who will you dance with, Jo?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You know I never dance.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I can’t dance.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Why can’t we all go to the party?! It’s not fair! Meg's hair is covered in papers, and Jo manipulates a pai hot tongs. Meg struggles to get on a pair of slippers.  12.

dialogues.speaker: JO MEG
dialogues.text: Just wear your regular (forcing it) /shoes. /These fit last winter! Amy puts on jewels and rouge and tries to shape her nose.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: My nose will simply not look refined.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (to no-one) I like your nose.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (reaching to Jo) Now, Jo --

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: -- don’t touch me, thanks! I already feel ridiculous I don’t want to look it!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You could be pretty if you tried.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Don't want to, won’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go but I wish I could hear all the music.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'll keep it all in my head and try to sing it for you when I get home. Jo goes back to working on Meg’s hair. Beth watches Jo ha the tongs, amazed and slightly worried:

dialogues.speaker: BETH JO
dialogues.text: Ought they to smoke /like (confident) that? /It's the dampness drying.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What a queer smell - it’s like... burnt feathers.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: There, now you'll see a perfect little ringlet.  13. Jo removes the tongs, and a burnt clump of hair follows. screams and Meg screams because Jo screams.

dialogues.speaker: AMY BETH
dialogues.text: (gasps, half delighted) /Why is her hair off? You're /ruined!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Meg, I’m so sorry!

dialogues.speaker: MEG JO
dialogues.text: (looking in the mirror) /I'm sorry! You shouldn't What have you done?! /Marmee have asked me to do it! I I’m spoilt! I can’t go! My ruin everything! hair! INT. GARDINER'S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861. Meg and Jo walk down the hallway at the Gardiner’s very f party, the party already in full swing. Meg is chastising

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Don’t stare, don’t put your hands behind your back, don’t say Christopher Columbus, don’t say Capital, don’t shake hands, don’t whistle -- Meg is immediately pulled away.

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE
dialogues.text: Meg March! You look so pretty! Sallie Moffat, at that moment Sallie Gardiner, pulls Meg from Jo, who is left standing awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Meg... Meg seems to put on another face and attitude, more grown and elegant. Jo fades away into the back of the party. INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861. Jo, 16, miserable, glumly watches the dancers. She pulls string on her dress. She catches Meg’s eyes, 17, laughing with her dance partner, and pleads with her to leave. Meg aggressively shakes her head, and Jo sighs, resigned. A very large red-headed boy makes a beeline for Jo - in h terror, she looks for an escape.  She slips behind sits on Theodore 17-year-old boy.
a curtain, and walking backwards, she nearly Laurence (!), Laurie, a very serious looking

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Dear me, I didn’t know any (rising) one /was here! /Don’t mind me; stay, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I won’t disturb you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Not at all; I don’t know many people, and felt rather strange at first, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: So do I. They stand there, unsure of what to do, both shy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Miss March, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Laurence, but I’m not Miss March, I’m only Jo.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: And I’m not Mr. Laurence, I’m only Laurie. Their first burst of conversation has run it’s course, an they smile at each other, standing in the not-unpleasant awkwardness of meeting.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Don’t you dance? I don’ yet -

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: t know how you do things here you see, I’ve spent most of my life in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: EUROPE! That’s CAPITAL! (she catches herself) I shouldn’t use words like that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Says who?  15.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Meg. She's my older sister. They peek through the curtain and watch Meg dance.

dialogues.speaker: JO LAURIE
dialogues.text: That’s her, see? The girl (looking) in the violet /dress? /Very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: She reminds me to be good so Father will be proud of me when he returns.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Volunteered for the Union Army. I wanted to go fight with him. I can’t get over my disappointment in being a girl. Laurie doesn’t look disappointed that she’s a girl at all

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Jo ... would you like to dance? With me?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I can’t, because...

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Because what?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You won’t tell?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Never!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I scorched my dress, see? Meg told me to keep still, so no one would see it. You can laugh if you want to. It’s funny, I know. Laurie does not laugh, but looks quite tender.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Never mind that; I’11 tell you how we can manage.  16. EXT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR'S PARTY. PORCH. NIGHT. 1861. Laurie bows, Jo awkwardly curtsies and then they go danci wildly up and down a wrap-around porch. It’s actually ver romantic in its exuberance. Sometimes Jo is the woman and sometimes the man - same with Laurie. They are mid-spin w they see Meg wildly gesture at them from inside: She’s hu

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: My foot- I’ve hurt my ankle. INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861. Meg limps, Jo supports her and Laurie trails behind.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: How will I get home?!

dialogues.speaker: JO MEG
dialogues.text: I don’t see what you can do /Carriages are too expensive. except get a carriage or stay /here all night.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Well, let me take you. It’s right next door.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: No, thank you, we cannot accept.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You must take mine. Please!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: No, it’s so early -- you can’t mean to leave yet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I always leave early - I do, truly.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What choice do you have? INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861. A laughing Marmee, holding a book and covered in flour, o the door on Laurie and Jo, supporting Meg.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Goodness gracious, what have you done!  17. Marmee has none of the pretensions of the other mothers, artifice. She’s a hippie before they existed. The little girls, Amy and Beth come rushing down the stai and attack the older girls.

dialogues.speaker: JO MEG
dialogues.text: Here, make room, /Meg is a /I sprained my ankle dancing! wounded soldier!

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Oh Meg - You’1l kill yourself for fashion one of these days. Hannah! We need ice!

dialogues.speaker: AMY BETH
dialogues.text: Tell us about it!/ (to Jo) (re: Laurie) /Was the music wonderful? What’s he like? Laurie stands apart, not wanting to be a disruption, but loving the March household, this slightly medieval utopia artists and thinkers.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Come in come in! Apologies for the chaos: I enjoy baking in the middle of the night! Don’t mind the clutter, Mr. Laurence, we don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Laurie, please.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (calling over) Can I call you Teddy?!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You must be part of the girls’ theatricals!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (pointedly) I'm Amy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Hello.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: They could use an extra player, although you’ll have to fight Jo for the male roles or play a girl. Here, have a scone. Marmee hands him the scone, as Hannah enters with ice for Meg's ankle. Amy keeps sneaking looks at Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (cracking herself up) Laurie, how are your ankles? Do you need ice?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) No, thank you, ma’am. Instantly, she sees his loneliness, his lack of a mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Oh, just call me Mother, or Marmee. Everyone does. He doesn’t say anything, but looks as if he’s about to cr He doesn’t have a mother, and hasn’t had one for a long t

dialogues.speaker: MEG JO
dialogues.text: It really seems like being a /I don’t believe fine young fine young lady to come home ladies enjoy themselves a bi from my party in a carriage more than we do. and have maids to /wait on me! The girls laugh and prance and gossip around the warm fir He stands apart, loving them all, the whole family... EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. CONTINUOUS. .--but most especially Jo. As Laurie retreats back to his big, lonely house, he looks across the field to Jo, writi alone in the attic, absorbed with her work.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRESENT. EXT./INT. NEW YORK BOARDING HOUSE. NIGHT. 18
dialogues.text: Jo works with her writing costume on: an antique military jacket. Her writing is like an attack, moving into enemy territory and occupying space. Her hand starts to cramp, shakes it, stretches it, and then switches hands. Suddenly she stops - she’s heard something. She opens the door, but the hallway is empty. She looks down and sees a book, a very beautiful copy of The Complete Works of Will Shakespeare. She opens the cover - inside there is a note  19.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: (read to camera) For the writer in the attic: Because you enjoyed the play so much tonight, I wanted you to have this. It will help you study character and paint it with your pen. dialogues.text: (reminded) Beth, after your shopping, I need you to work your way through the new sums and spelling and I‘1l check it all when I get home. Meg looks at the sun, and speeds up.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Hurry! I’1l be late! They break apart from each other at the fork in the road, Beth and Meg going one direction and Amy and Jo in anothe EXT. AUNT MARCH'S HOUSE. THE SAME DAY. 1862. Jo hops over a fence and runs toward Aunt March’s house. INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862. Aunt March dozes, poodle in her lap, while Jo stands by t bookcase and surreptitiously reads her own book.  38. She turns the page, trying to be as quiet as possible, bu Aunt March wakes up. AUNT MARCH (0.S.) Jo JOSY-/PHINE! (hiding her book) /Yes!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Is there a reason you stopped reading Belsham?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I’1l continue.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: (examining her) You mind yourself, dearie, one day you'll need me and you'll wish you had behaved better.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (carefully) Thank you, Aunt March, for your employment and many kindnesses, but I intend to make my own way in the world.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: No one makes their own way, not really, least of all a woman. You’1ll need to marry well.

dialogues.speaker: JO AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: You are not married, Aunt /Because I was rich and made /March. sure to keep my money.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: So the only way to be an unmarried woman is to be rich.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: But there are precious few ways for women to make money.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: That’s not true. You could run a cat house, or go on the stage. Practically the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (says nothing)  39.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Other than that, you’re right, precious few ways for women. That’s why you should heed me.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: So I can get married.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: No, so you can live a better life than your poor mother has.

dialogues.speaker: JO AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Marmee loves her /life. /You don’t know what she loves. Your father cared more about educating freedmen’s children than taking care of his family.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes, but he was right.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: It is possible to be right and foolish.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Well, you’re not paid to think.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softening slightly) I know you don’t care much about marriage now. I can’t say I blame you, but I intend to go to Europe one more time, and I need a companion. How would you like to be the person I take?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'd like that more than anything!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Then read and don’t sneak around. I don’t like sneaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During a break, one of the school girls whispers to Amy:

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: President Lincoln.  40.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No! Father is fighting for him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: My father says the war is a (shocked) waste, we should just let /It is immoral! them keep /their labor.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Everyone benefited from the system, including you Marches - why should only the south be punished?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should all be punished.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: The Marches love a cause.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Fine, just do Mr. Davis.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I should.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: I'll wipe out your debt and give you five more limes besides. Amy is seduced, and instantly starts drawing the (very go and accurate) caricature. The girls giggle. Amy gets carr away, drawing a conversation bubble with words “My eye is upon you, young ladies.” More laughter. Suddenly, a shado falls over them, and all the girls look up, scared, and m away. Amy, however, is too wrapped up in her drawing to notice. When she does, Mr. Davis looks down sternly at he INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862. Laurie tries very hard to study with his tutor, Mr. Brook but it is hopeless, Laurie keeps jumping up and distracti himself with something in the room. His most recent posit is standing like a statue, perched on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: Sit down. Sit down, Laurie. Latin is a privilege. Please, you have to learn this. I can’t afford to lose this position. Just return to Cicero. But Laurie is staring out the window.  41.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: There’s a girl out there.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: No, there is not.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: YES! Mr. Brooke, there is a girl! He throws open the window and yells out:

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Hello there! Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (sniffling but yelling) I’m Amy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Hello Amy, I’m Laurie!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I know. You brought my sister back from the dance - I would have never sprained MY ankle, I have lovely small feet. Best in my family. But I can never go home again, I’m in such trouble. Look. She holds up her hand, which is red and bleeding a little

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Davis hit me. INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862. Amy, her hand now bandaged, sits looking at an art book, pretending to be a very fine lady.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (doing a voice) Tell the servants that I want this painting purchased for me!

dialogues.speaker: IMMEDIATELY
dialogues.text: Laurie laughs at this confident girl. Amy likes making hi laugh. Mr. Brooke shakes his head, frustrated. A servant enters, followed by Jo and Meg.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: (indicating Amy) She’s in here...  42. Meg goes instantly to Amy, while Jo gets distracted by al the books. Laurie stands when Jo enters:

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE JO
dialogues.text: Jo! (bursting out) What richness! Theodore Lawrence you ought to be the happiest boy in the world!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: A fellow can’t live on books alone.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I could. Meg is tending to Amy, and Mr. Brooke can’t help but star Meg, completely flummoxed by her beauty and goodness:

dialogues.speaker: MEG JO
dialogues.text: What happened /little lamb? (suspicious, to Amy) /What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (playing innocent) Just a drawing and then... Mr. Davis hit me. Amy starts crying again, holds up her hand. Meg has taken her gloves and put them on a side table while she examine her sister's outstretched hand. Mr. Brooke eyes the glove he’s drawn to the items so recently worn by Meg. Jo, who has been roaming the room, stops in front of a portrait of Mr. Laurence. Laurie follows her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Christopher Columbus, look at that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: That’s my grandfather. Are you scared of him?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I’m not scared of anyone! He looks stern, but my grandfather was much more handsome. Unfortunately, during this speech, Mr. Laurence has enter with Mrs. March, unseen by Jo.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Jo! We do not compare grandfathers!  43. Jo spins around and sees Mr. Laurence and her mother.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: You think he’s more handsome, hey?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You are very handsome. I didn’t mean...

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (cracking half a smile) I knew your mother’s father. You’ve got his spirit.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Marmee tends to Amy.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You are not to attend that school any more.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Good, that man has always been an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Jo will teach you.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: ME?! I already teach Beth!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: You’re a good teacher.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: (trying with Meg) Yes, women being taught at home is much more proper, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (turning to him) Only because the schools for women are so poor.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: Indeed, quite right.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I wish all the girls would leave his horrible school and that he would die.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You did wrong, Amy, and there will be consequences. (to Laurie) Thank you so much for taking care of Amy. My girls do have a way of getting into mischief.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: So do I!

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Then you should run over and we'll take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE JO
dialogues.text: And please come here, /YES! Beth would adore the whenever you'd like. And tell piano! Beth to come /too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Is she the quiet one?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: That’s our Beth.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (pretend business-like) Tell the little girl to use our piano.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: And Jo, borrow any book you'd like!

dialogues.speaker: AMY MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: And may I come look /at the (to Meg) paintings? /There is also a lovely greenhouse..

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: We must be going. Girls?

dialogues.speaker: JO/AMY /MEG
dialogues.text: Thank you/ Please come over/Many thanks/Our apologies. The women leave and Mr. Brooke notices Meg has left her g behind.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Meg! You forgot your glove!  45. The men are left standing in the silence of their absence Mr. Laurence breaks the spell:

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Well, back to work, back to work. THE PRESENT. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. Jo looks towards the Laurence’s house, which is dark, shutters closed. It doesn’t seem right without Laurie in She looks in the forest by the pond to find an old mailbo She produces a key with a red ribbon and holds it in her hand, and we and she are transported back to.... THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862. Meg, Beth, Jo and Amy are all dressed as men, with hats a spectacles and pipes - Meg reading from the homemade newspaper in her lovely sonorous voice.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (finishing) A NEW PLAY, written by Miss Jo March, will appear at the Barnville Theatre, in the course of the next few weeks, which will surpass anything ever seen before on the American stage.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Starring the greatest actress from here to the Mississippi River, Miss Meg March.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: WEEKLY REPORT Meg— Good. Jo— Bad. Beth— Very Good. Amy— Middling.

dialogues.speaker: BETH AMY
dialogues.text: Excellent. Well done, sirs.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Mr. President and gentlemen, I wish to propose the admission of a new member. One who highly deserves the honor, would be deeply grateful, and would add immensely to the spirit of the club. I propose Mr. Theodore Laurence!

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: No! Absolutely not!  46.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (breaking formality) Come now, let’s have him.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He’s a real boy!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: We don't want any boys. This is a club for ladies.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I think we should to do it, even if we are afraid. I say yes. It’s Laurie!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Now then, everybody vote, and remember that it’s our Laurie and say “AYE!”

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Aye. Aye.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: And, as there is no time like the present! Jo throws open the doors of the closet, and Laurie is the already dressed for the occasion of the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: AMY MEG
dialogues.text: You /traitor! /You rogue!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Ladies, please - this is my stratagem, I deserve the blame: Jo only gave into it after lots of teasing. Laurie bows deeply.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Hear hear!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I merely wish to say, that as a slight token of my gratitude and as a means of promoting friendly relations between adjoining nations, I propose this set of keys for a little post office I’ve made in the forest by the pond.  47.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Allow me to present four copies of the key, and with many thanks for your favor, take my seat as part of the club. He lays the four keys (with different colored ribbons) be them and bows again and they all cheer. THE PRESENT. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. Jo holds the very same key and opens the post office box nothing, of course. She shuts it back up and trudges acro the field to her childhood home. INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869. Jo walks in the kitchen, and is immediately surrounded by Hannah, Meg, Marmee, and Demi and Daisy. They unload her and sit her in a chair and pepper her with questions.

dialogues.speaker: JO HANNAH
dialogues.text: Hello! Thank God you’re home!

dialogues.speaker: MEG MARMEE
dialogues.text: Oh Jo I’ve missed you! We could have come to get you!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (leaning down to the children) Daisy and Demi! You’ve gotten so big!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I wish you were here to teach them...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (hugging Meg) I’m here now...

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: It’s so good to have you home! I think the loneliness got to Beth, though she ain’t said anything.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Beth, where is Beth? Jo turns to Marmee, who shows the truth in her eyes.  48.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: She's upstairs. Oh, my Jo. We all thought she was better but the fever had weakened her heart. Jo produces an envelope full of money.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Take this and find her the best doctor you can.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: No, you need this money to live in New York.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) I’m not going back. I’m using the rest to take her to the sea and get her strong. She hugs all the women again.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: When is Amy coming home? Marmee and Meg exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: We didn’t want to worry her.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (sharply) Does she not know?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Beth insisted we not tell her because she didn’t want to ruin Amy's trip.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (rueful) Amy has always had a talent for getting out of the hard parts of life.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Jo, don’t be angry with your sister...  49. THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EVENING. 1862. Jo, in her and Meg's room, places a pretty cover page on of the novel she has written. She lovingly writes “For Father,” and hears:

dialogues.speaker: MEG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jo! Jo, where are you? I can’t find my other glove!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (hollering)

dialogues.speaker: TAKE MINE
dialogues.text: Jo puts her novel carefully in a drawer that is filled wi her finished writing, and closes it.

dialogues.speaker: MEG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jo we're going to be late!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (entering) You're not invited.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You are going somewhere with Laurie, I know it!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes, we are, now stop bothering.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Do you have the tickets?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes! Hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You're going to the theatre with Laurie. Meg, please, can I come?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, dear, but you weren’t invited.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You can’t go Amy, so don’t be a baby and whine about it.  50.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’ve been shut up in here and I never get to go anywhere. Beth has her piano but I’m so lonely!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (from the piano) I can teach you chords.

dialogues.speaker: AMY JO
dialogues.text: I don’t want chords, I want NO. I think you’d hate to to go to the /theatre! poke yourself in where you’re not wanted. We already have to deal with dull Mr. Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I like him, he’s kind.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’ll pay for myself!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You will not come.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, my sweet, but Jo is right. Next time.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (leaving) Come, Meg, stop petting her!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You'll be sorry for this Jo March! You will! You’1l regret this! INT. THEATRE. NIGHT. 1862. Jo and Meg watch the play, which is a campy vaudeville ki of thing. They are completely engaged in the proceedings. men are watching them: Laurie looks at Jo while Mr. Brook looks at Meg. INT. JO AND MEG’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Amy sneaks into Jo and Meg’s room, searching every drawer hiding place for the novel that she knows is there. She finally finds it in the bureau. She pulls out the novel t Jo has just lovingly placed there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they leave the theatre, Mr. Brooke offers Meg his arm, she takes it. Jo notices and doesn’t like it at all.  51. Laurie sees Jo’s expression and offers his own arm in moc chivalry. She punches him in the shoulder, and then races taking her sister’s other arm, pulling her away from Mr. Brooke. INT. KITCHEN. EVENING. 1862. Amy places page after page into the fire, watching it bur and feeling nothing but terrific about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg and Jo waltz in. Beth is playing with her dolls and A is sitting and reading, suspiciously quiet. Jo sprints upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (yelling down as she runs up the stairs) Meg you’re a million times better than she was - although she was a terrific fainter!

dialogues.speaker: MEG JO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (musing to herself) /Ugh, that Mr. Brooke, could I wonder how she managed to he be any more... obsequious? turn white /as she did?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (hollering back) I thought he was very well- mannered.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (from upstairs) Hold on, let me just get this idea down.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Beth what’s your favorite eye color?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (quickly) Purple.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (wrapped up in her own story) Mr. Brooke has blue eyes and an old soul which is much more important than money. Jo re-appears, walking slowly.  52.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Has anyone taken my novel?

dialogues.speaker: MEG BETH
dialogues.text: No. No. Why? Amy starts reading even more intently than before.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Amy... you’ve got it.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No I haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (grabbing her shoulders) That’s a lie!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It isn’t! I haven’t got it - I don’t know where it is and I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: JO MEG
dialogues.text: Tell me or /I’'1l make you! (trying to hold her back) /Jo, don't! (calling)

dialogues.speaker: I BURNT IT UP
dialogues.text: BOOK! I TOLD YOU I’D MAKE YOU PAY

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You wicked girl! You wicked, wicked girl! I can never write it again! I'll never forgive you as long as I live!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are fighting, full-out fighting, during these last lines, as their sisters and Marmee attempt to stop it. INT. JO’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Jo is weeping, Beth cradling her head, Meg holds her hand Marmee enters with Amy, who looks penitent. Marmee nods a her, as if to say “go ahead”:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Jo.  53. Nothing from Jo.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Amy...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (a rush of words) It’s just that the only thing you care about is your writing so it’s not as if I could hurt you by ruining one of your dresses. And I really did want to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am the most sorry for it now. I’m so sorry. Marmee approaches the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Don’t let the sun go down on your anger. Forgive her. Help each other, and you begin again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (running from the room) She doesn’t deserve my forgiveness. I will hate her! I will hate her forever! INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. MORNING. 1862. A very tense breakfast: Jo’s eyes are red and puffy and a remorseful Amy tries to sit beside her and make peace, bu changes seats away from her. Amy looks pleadingly at Meg. Laurie bursts open the back door, unaware of all the trou

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Good morning ladies! It’s brisk and brilliant and I think the last day for the river - get your ice skates! Jo springs up, thrilled to have something to do.

dialogues.speaker: JO AMY
dialogues.text: One second! Go down, and I’11 /I want to come too! Last /be right there! time you promised I could go! Jo, not acknowledging her, grabs her skates and races out  54.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (wailing) Is she going to be like this forever?!

dialogues.speaker: BETH AMY
dialogues.text: It was a very hard loss /for /Is there nothing I can do? her.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially) Go after her. Don't say anything till Jo has got good-natured with Laurie, then take a quiet minute and just kiss her, or do some kind thing, and I'm sure she'll be friends again. Heartened, Amy grabs her skates. EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862. Amy runs out of the house, calling:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Wait for me! Please! Jo pretends not to hear, skating near the edge while Laur tests the ice. Amy is just getting to the riverbank, wavi and calling.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Hello! Wait for me!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Stay near the edge, it’s not safe in the middle! Jo hesitates for a moment, and looks at Amy, who struggle with her skates - it’s not clear whether or not she heard Laurie. Jo opens her mouth to say something, but changes mind. The anger in her heart has made her small and mean.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (to Jo, not seeing Amy) Ready? Jo takes off down the ice, jumping the gun, Laurie racing after her. Meanwhile, Amy tentatively steps onto the ice. She begins gliding, arms out, a younger and less experienced skater.  55. Farther along the river, Laurie and Jo are trying tricks spins, when Jo suddenly feels a pang of guilt, but shoves feelings down and races to catch Laurie. She plows into Laurie, toppling him. They are both laughi when just at that moment - CRRAACCCKKK. The sound of ice splitting. And a high pitched scream:

dialogues.speaker: HELP
dialogues.text: Laurie and Jo freeze and look at each other, and in the s instant they scramble up, Jo screaming.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Amy! It’s AMY! They race back, Jo sending up a breathless prayer, an incantation, a pleading with the universe:

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh god, oh god, dear god please... They find Amy surfacing and screaming and then going back under. Jo is almost paralyzed with terror...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No... no... .-. but Laurie has leapt to action.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Jo! Get a branch! Jo obeys quickly, blindly, using the incredible strength is available to people in times of crises - Jo drags a la branch over to Laurie, who stretches it over to Amy:

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Grab on! She does, and Laurie and Jo both lie flat on their stomac so as not to disturb the ice, as they pull together. Jo i terrified but keeping herself together to get Amy to safe The effort makes her own hands bleed. She and Laurie give last pull and Amy is back on firm ground. Tears are streaming down Jo’s face as she strips off all warm clothes and bundles them around Amy.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: My sister, my sister, dear God thank you for my sweet sister.  56. INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Amy is asleep, covered in blankets. Jo is slumped down on floor beside her, not even feeling herself worthy of a ch Marmee adjusts Amy’s blanket, and then looking at Jo, dec to take a seat beside her, on the floor:

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: She’s asleep.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: If she had died it would've been my fault.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) She will be fine, the doctor said he didn’t even think she’d catch cold.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What is wrong with me? I’ve made so many resolutions and written sad notes and cried over my sins but it doesn’t seem to help. When I get in a passion I get so savage, I could hurt anyone and enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You remind me of myself.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: But you’re never angry.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (honestly) I’m angry nearly every day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I’m not patient by nature, but with nearly forty years of effort I have learned to not let it get the better of me.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (resolutely) I'll do the same, then. Marmee touches her daughters face.  57.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I hope you'll do a great deal better than me. There are some natures too noble to curb, too lofty to bend. The two women sit beside each other as Amy sleeps. Jo put her head on Marmee’s shoulder. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869. Jo, sitting by the bed, watches over Beth as she did for She attempts to write while Beth sleeps. She keeps starti crossing things out. She is divinely dissatisfied. She gives up and picks up one of Amy’s letters. As she’s reading, Beth opens her eyes and sees Jo sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Jo.

dialogues.speaker: JO BETH
dialogues.text: Oh, Beth! My /love! /You didn’t need to come...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I never should’ve left. Do you need anything? Here take some water.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s so good to see your face.

dialogues.speaker: JO BETH
dialogues.text: We're going to the sea to get /The sea! you strong and /well.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I want you dancing by the time Amy gets back.

dialogues.speaker: BETH JO
dialogues.text: (worried) No, no... She's not cutting her trip short, /is she?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Good. Is there any news? What does she say?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: She writes that Laurie is there... I’m glad he’s with her, he won't respond to any of my letters.  58.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Do you miss him?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (tearing up) I miss everything.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I know. Jo bows her head on Beth’s bed. THE PAST. EXT. LAURENCE HOUSE. SPRING DAY. 1862. Meg is saying goodbye to everyone as she sets off for her adventure to visit Annie Moffat. Mr. Brooke is carrying h baggage, Hannah and the sisters and Marmee are helping wi odds and ends, Laurie is “boxing” with Jo, and Mr. Lauren is there in his proper, “over-seeing-things” kind of way.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Coming!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (to Laurie) You take the other carriage and surprise her - make sure she doesn’t fall in love!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE MEG
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain /Jo! (to her Mother) /It was so kind of Annie to invite me. Thank you for letting me go, Marmee.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Just be who you are, my sweet Meg. (handing her a necklace) It was mine when I was your age.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Oh mother! Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I’ve never understood saving jewelry until marriage - pretty things should be enjoyed.  59.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (to Laurie, while kneeling and removing a ring from her finger) Yes, pretty things should be enjoyed. Jo places the ring in Laurie’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (pouting) I wish I could go to the debutante ball.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: (aside to Marmee) Do you think this is a good idea, her going away like this?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Girls have to go into the world and make up their own minds about things.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (to Meg) Don’t forget about us.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I won’t Jo, it’s only a week!

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: (handing a pair of shoes to Marmee) She needs to have some decent shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Thank you again for the carriage, Mr. Laurence. I don’t know how to repay you.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Nonsense! Although, there is one thing -

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Anything! For a second, Mr. Laurence’s eyes flick to Beth - but the directs his comments to Marmee.  60.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: It occurred to me today that my daughter’s piano suffers from want of use.

dialogues.speaker: MEG JO
dialogues.text: Does /it? /Shhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Wouldn't one of your girls like to run over, and practice on it now and then, just to keep it in tune? If they don't care to come, why, never mind.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (bursting out) Oh sir, they do care, very very much!

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (gently) Are you the musical girl?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I love it dearly, and I'll come, if you are quite sure nobody will hear me, and be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Not a soul, my dear. (to the driver) Drive on, and keep her safe! Meg is pulled away by a carriage, and waves goodbye to everyone, they run down the road after her. EXT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. BOSTON. DAY. 1862. Meg arrives at a very grand, beautiful house, and suddenl feels quite self-conscious in her clothes. INT/EXT. LAURENCE HOUSE. DAY. 1862. Mr. Laurence watches from an upper window as a very timid Beth tries to walk bravely across the lawn. She stops, an turns back and walks towards her house, and then turns ar again, finally making it all the way into the Laurence ho INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862. All the other girls are in their fabulous dresses, paradi up the grand staircase. Meg trails in her plain dress.  61.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Now what dress will you wear tonight, Meg?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (ashamed, but hiding it) I will wear this one.

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE
dialogues.text: That one? Can’t you send home for another?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I haven’t got another.

dialogues.speaker: SALLIE
dialogues.text: Only the one? Oh, that’s so /funny.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (jumping in) /Not at all. There’s no need of sending home, Daisy - I’m going to call you Daisy now - I’ve got a sweet pink dress laid away, and you will wear it to please me, won't you, Daisy?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: If it’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Of course! INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. DAY. 1862. Beth enters the big house and makes her way to the conservatory, looking at the piano with love. INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. STAIRS. DAY. 1862. All the young men in their tuxedos wait for the young wom to descend down the grand staircase - their parents watch proudly. The young ladies walk down the stairs like fancy Easter Eggs, Meg the most beautiful of all. She’s a trium INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862. Meg is done up nearly beyond recognition. She’s powdered corseted and drinking and flirting. In fact, she’s kind o great at it.  62.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Everyone is in love with you, Daisy! You have to keep my dress.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I can’t keep your dress! Suddenly, Laurie is standing in front of her. Meg starts.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Have fun, little Daisy. And Annie retreats with her friends, giggling again.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (trying to be normal) Laurie! I didn’t know you were going to come!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: And what a lovely surprise it is.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Why are they calling you “Daisy”?

dialogues.speaker: MEG LAURIE
dialogues.text: It's their pet name /for me. /Meg is a perfectly good name.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: It’s just like playing a part, to be Daisy for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: What would Jo say? Meg says nothing but looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t actually marry one of these men, would you?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I might.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (re: her champagne) You'll have a terrible headache tomorrow.  63.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: It’s a good thing that it’s still tonight, then. (then) Do you like the way I look?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MEG LAURIE
dialogues.text: Why /not? /I don’t like fuss and feathers.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: You...you are the rudest boy I ever saw! Meg, in her anger and hurt, inelegantly hands him her champagne and accepts a dance with the boy standing neare INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. DAY. 1862. A very nervous Beth sits down and sees the sheet music in front of her. At first she is tentative, trying to play quietly, but soon she plays with abandon. She is on fire. Laurence, sitting on the stairs, is deeply moved by Beth’ music. Tears stream down his face. INT. MOFFAT BALLROOM. NIGHT. 1862. Meg feels faint from the corset and the champagne, and le her head against a cool windowpane, hot and ashamed. Laur comes and sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Please forgive me and come dance.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (still hurt) I'm afraid it would be too disagreeable for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like your dress, but I think you are just... splendid. Meg smiles, and Laurie smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I know it’s silly, but please don’t tell Jo. Let me have my fun tonight. I'll be desperately good for the rest of my life.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them are now dancing, looking young and sincer and terrific. They whirl and spin and laugh and the music plays on as the picture changes to... THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869. Meg sits scared and ashamed, and John - Mr. Brooke, intelligent and kind and handsome - examines the two ledg books. He struggles to understand.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, John. The silk was the first real expense.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (making the best of it) Fifty dollars, while a lot, is not, I suppose, too much for a dress, with all the notions that are needed to finish it these days.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not exactly even a dress yet... It’s just the fabric. John takes off his glasses, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, I see.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (working herself up) I know you are angry, John. I don't mean to waste your money, but I can't resist when I see Sallie buying all she wants, and pitying me because I don't. I try to be contented, but it is hard, and, and... (honestly and quietly) I'm tired of being poor. John bows his head, wounded.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I was afraid of this. I do my best, Meg. Instantly regretful, Meg begs forgiveness:  65.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Oh, John, my dear, kind, hard- working boy. I didn't mean it! It was so wicked, so untrue and ungrateful, how could I say it!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (sadly) Perhaps you meant it.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: No! Not a bit! We’ll figure out a way to get you your coat as well, and then won’t we be grand, the two of us?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (pats her hand, rises) I can’t afford it, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: John, but --

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I need to go to bed. John gets up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pausing, but not turning around) And I really am very sorry that you have had to do without so many beautiful things. And that you're married to someone who can’t give them to you. He leaves, and she is terrified that she’s broken the man loves so much. INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869. Amy is looking through her own paintings and sketches and a disturbed expression on her face. Laurie enters. His lo life is always to be apologizing to one March sister or another, and he looks truly contrite.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Hello Amy!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (not turning around) I don’t want to see you.  66.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Amy I’m so sorry for how I behaved. Please? Forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: AMY LAURIE
dialogues.text: (still not turning) /Only a little, and it’s 4pm, Have you been drinking you can’t be too hard on me. /again?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Someone has to do it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: So when do you begin your great work of art, Raphaella?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (finally turning) Never. He sees her face, the ashen worry traced on it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: What - why?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (grim) I’m a failure. Jo is in New York, being a writer, and I am a failure.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: That’s quite a statement to make at twenty.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Rome took all the vanity out of me. And Paris made me realize I’d never be a genius. I’m giving up all my foolish artistic hopes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Why should you? You have so much talent and energy.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Talent isn’t genius, and no amount of energy can make it so. I want to be great, or nothing. I won’t be a common-place dauber, so I don’t intend to try anymore. Laurie watches her and then says conspiratorially:  67.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: What women are allowed into the club of geniuses anyway?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: The Brontes?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: And who always declares genius?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, men, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: They're cutting down the competition.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: That's a very complicated argument to make me feel better.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Do you though? Feel better?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I do think that male or female, I’m a middling talent.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Middling talent? Then may I ask your last portrait be of me? Amy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Now that you’ve given up all your foolish artistic hopes, what are you going to do with your life?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Polish up my other talents and be an ornament to society.  68.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Here is where Fred Vaughn comes in, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: AMY LAURIE
dialogues.text: Don’t make /fun! (laughing) /I'm not!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You are not engaged, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: But you will be, if he goes down properly on one knee?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Most likely, yes.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He’s rich, richer than you, even.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I understand queens of society can’t get on without money. But it does sound odd coming from one of your mother’s girls.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’ve always known that I would marry rich. Why should I be ashamed of that?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: There is nothing to be ashamed of, as long as you love him.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, I believe we have some power over who we love, it isn’t something that just happens to a person.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I think the poets might disagree.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well. I’m not a poet, I’m just a woman. And as a woman I have no way to make money, not enough to earn a living and support my family.  69.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even if I had my own money, which I don’t, it would belong to my husband the minute we were married. If we had children they would belong to him not me. They would be his property. So don’t sit there and tell me that marriage isn’t an economic proposition, because it is. It may not be for you but it most certainly is for me. The sound of a carriage approaching, and Amy gives a litt start:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: That will be Fred now. (to Laurie) How do I look? Do I look all right? Laurie looks at her, really looks at her for the first ti

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You look beautiful. You are... beautiful. She suddenly blushes, but smiles in thanks. And then runs to greet Fred. From the top of the staircase, Laurie look her and Fred embrace, not sure of what he’s feeling. THE PAST. EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862. On a perfect spring day, Laurie, playing the host, makes introductions of the British family to the March women. A he introduces Fred Vaughn, who, of course, we already kno Amy's potential husband.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: This is Fred Vaughn, (a handsome young man) and his sister Kate, (a prim looking girl) and of course you know Mr. Brooke - and this is Meg, Amy, Beth and Jo. Jo tips her oversized hat.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (British accent) So pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, how elegant.  70.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (suddenly intense) Remember the name “Amy March.” I'm going to come find you one day in London.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, I certainly will! EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

dialogues.speaker: KITES
dialogues.text: - A badminton game between Fred and Amy on one team and J and Laurie on the other while Beth cheers on both sides. - Sallie tries to impress Kate and flirt with Fred. - Fred tries to flirt with Jo, who kicks him. - Everyone flies kites. - Jo and Laurie run into the ocean. - Amy settles with a sketchpad, drawing Laurie - this is picture we will see later (earlier).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Mr. Brooke and Meg are talking and flirting and skippin stones and generally being adorable and have that look of intimacy. - Jo, trying to practice her badminton skills, keeps look over at Meg, who gazes at Mr. Brooke adoringly. This anno Jo. Laurie sees her and comes and whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (whispering to Jo) I know something you don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (whispering back) Tell me this second!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (devilish) Has Meg perhaps mislaid a glove? Jo whips around to look at Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (sharp) Mr. Brooke has it? (Laurie nods) How do you know?  71.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Saw it.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: All this time?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Yes, isn’t it romantic?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No, it’s horrid.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be pleased.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: At the idea of anybody coming to take Meg away? No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You'll feel better about it when somebody comes to take you away.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'd like to see anyone try it!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: So would I! More scenes of childhood on the beach play out over the s of Jo's voice reading The Mill on the Floss by George Eli

dialogues.speaker: JO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “We could never have loved the earth so well if we had had no childhood in it, if it were not the earth where the same flowers come up again every spring that we used to gather with our tiny fingers.” THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869. Beth is wrapped up and looking at the sea and Jo reads Ge Eliot's “The Mill On the Floss.” The beach is emptier, darker, colder -- the beach of their adulthood, without t gloss of memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “What novelty is worth that sweet monotony where everything is known and loved because it is known?” (to Beth) How great is that?!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (nods, then) I love to listen to you read, Jo, but I love it even better when you read the stories you’ve written.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) I don’t have any new stories.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Haven't written any.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You have pencil and paper. Sit here and write me something.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Uhh. I can’t, I don’t think I can anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It’s just, no one even cares to hear my stories anyway.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Write something for me. You’re a writer. Even before anyone knew or paid you. I’m very sick and you must do what I say. Jo smiles and then lays back.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do what Marmee taught us to do. Do it for someone else. Jo is quiet. Sometimes it’s hard when someone knows you.  73. THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862. Men, and a handful of women, are busily working in a converted warehouse with soldiers, veterans and volunteer

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: If you’re walking to Vermont, there is Mrs. Sewell in Keene New Hampshire who will give you room and board.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN ROBBINS
dialogues.text: You should go home to the girls, I can take care of this.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I need to be here. I've spent my whole life ashamed of my country.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN ROBBINS
dialogues.text: No offense meant but you should still be ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I know, I am. And older man, worn with age and grief, approaches her ta He is almost too shy to talk to her. She sees him, and pu him at ease.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Can I help you sir?

dialogues.speaker: ASA MELVIN
dialogues.text: Hello Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Have you sons in the Army?

dialogues.speaker: ASA MELVIN
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am; I had four, but two were killed; one is a prisoner, and I'm going to the other, who is very sick in a Washington hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You have done a great deal for your country sir.

dialogues.speaker: ASA MELVIN
dialogues.text: Not a mite more than I ought, ma'am. I'd go myself, if I was any use; as I ain't, I give my boys.  74. Marmee fights her tears, busying herself with arranging a charity bundle for him. She notices that he doesn't have good scarf, so gives him her own, careful that he doesn't this kindness. As she's doing this, a soldier walks up:

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Mrs. March?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Telegram from Washington Ma'am. He holds a telegram, the thing Marmee dreads. INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862. Everything is topsy-turvy in the March house, anxious and worried. Hannah and Meg run about getting everything read Beth cries but tries not to, Amy packs her mother’s trunk

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Is Jo back yet from Aunt March?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t seen her.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (worried) I can’t miss the last train... Mr. Laurence and Laurie enter.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (hugging Beth) What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (to Marmee) If I may be of any more assistance, please tell me. I will look in on the girls every day, without fail.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Thank you, for everything.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: I have always admired your husband, and I pray for a quick recovery. Meg is nearly running in the hallway when she bumps strai into Mr. Brooke.  75.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (looking up) Oh - I’m, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROOKE
dialogues.text: I came to offer myself as escort to your mother. Mr. Laurence has commissions for me in Washington, and it will give me real satisfaction to be of service to her there. Meg spontaneously kisses him on the cheek. Instead of bei embarrassed, Meg looks at him with pure gratitude and say

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Thank you. Meg runs back into the living room, followed by a stunned Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: While I’m gone, Hannah is in charge - and please remember to check on the Hummel’s, it will be a difficult winter for everyone... At just that moment, the door swings open, and Jo rushes and places money in her mother’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Will this be enough for the train?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Twenty five dollars! That isn’t like Aunt March to be so generous.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I didn’t go to Aunt March, couldn’t bear to.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Where did you get the money?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I only sold what was my own. Jo removes her hat, and beneath, all of her beautiful lon hair is gone - now it’s just a short, blunt crop. Gasps f everyone and exclamations of “What?/How?/Why did you do it?/Jol"

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Your hair!  76.

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: Oh Jo, how could /you? /Your one beauty!

dialogues.speaker: BETH HANNAH
dialogues.text: Now your hair is /off. /You look like a boy.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It doesn’t affect the fate of the nation, so don’t wail.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (leaning close to Jo) I am so proud that you are my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (just to her mother) I was crazy to do something for Father. It’ll be good for my vanity, anyway. Jo runs to Laurie, hugging him. They now look like twin b and they both ruffle each other’s hair. My

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: girls: I love you more than words can say. Be good to each other. Pray for Father’s recovery. I will come back as soon as I can. The men watch solemnly, more determined than ever to help these women that they care for so deeply. INT. MARCH HOUSE. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1862. Jo sits alone tries to make and Amy walks oh, No. in the hallway, quietly weeping to herself. She as little noise as possible, but a door opens out - she stoops down to comfort her sister.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Jo. Is it Father?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: +. It’s my hair. And she sobs and sobs into Amy’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (getting emotional too) I would feel the same way.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I know you would.  77. The two sisters, so different, sit and comfort each other THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869. Laurie lazily lolls on the grass of the beautiful estate, while Amy sketches him. A peace has settled over them, they’re friends again. Amy gives him a hard time, playful

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Laurie, when are you going back to your grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Very soon.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
