dialogues.text: You've said that a dozen times in the past month.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Short answers save trouble.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He expects you, so why don’t you do it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Natural depravity, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Natural indolence, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I'll only plague him if I go, so I might as well stay and plague you a little longer. He jumps up and play fights with her, making her laugh. H captures her, and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can bear it. In fact, I think it agrees with you. Amy disentangles herself. She goes back to drawing:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (cheeky ) Looking at you.  78.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (stern) No, I mean what do you intend. To do.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Oh you mean with life?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE AMY
dialogues.text: I've been writing an opera, /That's a waste of time. I'd be the central /figure...

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: What would you have me do?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Go back and work for your grandfather and make something of yourself. She watches him and he watches her.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Here. Laurie comes around to look at the sketch - and sees anot sketch beside it from years ago, young and full of happin

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (he picks it up, touched) When did you do this one?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It was the day at the beach, when I met Fred for the first time. The mention of Fred changes the air.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: When is he coming back?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (inexplicably embarrassed) A week or two... he has business in London. Laurie gets very intense all of the sudden, words rush ou

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Don’t marry him.  79.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Don’t marry him.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You know why.... He takes her hand, and she pulls it away. THE PAST.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No, Laurie, that’s mean, it’s just mean of you...

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I have been second to Jo my whole life in everything and I will not be the person you settle for just because you cannot have her. I won’t do it, not when, not when I’ve spent my entire life loving you. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862. Amy has her foot in a bucket of plaster, working on makin mold. Meg is reading a letter, smiling to herself. Jo wri a story. Beth finishes a pair of slippers for Mr. Laurenc The room is messy - they’ve let things slide since their mother has been gone. It was never a neat house, but now definitely isn’t. The inmates are running the asylum.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I'm making a mold of my foot for Laurie to remind him I have nice feet.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Mr. Brooke writes that Father is still very weak, but improving. Mr. Brooke also says Mother is the best nurse a man could have...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I wish all the letters were from Mother, and not Mr. Brooke.  80.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I’m grateful for any letters. Meg, with careful attention, places the letter away and starts working on an errands list.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I think the deep purple is very fitting for Mr. Laurence, do you agree Amy?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (glancing over) Quite. And the design is very cunning. Amy returns to her task.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I had to thank him somehow for allowing me to play the piano at his house all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I‘1ll go into town for groceries - Jo, can you go look into getting more firewood?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You all haven’t been to see the Hummel’s. We should go.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh Bethy we barely have enough to feed ourselves. Besides, I have to finish this story.

dialogues.speaker: BETH AMY
dialogues.text: Marmee said /that we /Marmee said so many things we can’t possibly do them all.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: But I always go by myself and you haven't been keeping up with your tasks...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: We work!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Don’t worry sweet girl, we’ll find a time.  81.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: But it’s been weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: We’ll go soon.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: MY FOOT IS STUCK! I CAN’T GET IT out! Jo laughs and tries to help her pull her foot out, while Beth’s little face turns stubborn. She doesn’t like this.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Fine, I’ll go myself. EXT. LAURENCE HOUSE. MORNING. 1862. Beth gives her slippers, wrapped up, to a servant. EXT. WOODS./HUMMEL HOUSE. AFTERNOON. 1862. Beth, all alone, with a basket of supplies, makes her way towards the Hummel’s. A baby is crying, a panicked, sick EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862. Beth returns to her home, walking slowly, and feeling strange. Her sisters’ heads bob up and down in the window

dialogues.speaker: JO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Here she comes! Beth walks in, and a letter is placed in her hand:

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Here’s a letter from the old gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Beth look what they got you -- But Jo clamps a hand over Amy’s mouth - Meg takes Beth’s and leads her to where the old piano used to stand, and i its place, a beautiful little piano forte.

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: Look! Open the note!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) Jo... read it, I cannot.  82.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: “Miss Beth March, I have had many pairs of slippers in my life, but I never had any that suited me so well as yours. And they will always remind me of the gentle giver. I like to pay my debts, and hope you will accept this gift. Your grateful friend and humble servant, James Laurence.” (whoops with joy!)

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: “Humble servant” /how lovely! (examining) /See the cunning brackets to hold candles, and the nice green silk... They are so absorbed in the piano, that they almost don’t notice that Beth has gotten up and walked straight over t the Laurence’s house. EXT./INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. MR. LAURENCE’S OFFICE. DAY. 186 Timid Beth walks straight up to the house and then to Mr. Laurence’s office and tries to speak:

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Sir, I wanted to thank you... But words are lost, and she throws her arms around him. H accepts the hug like he’s been waiting for it his whole l

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: You remind me so much of my little girl. The piano is yours, I should have given it to you long ago. While he’s hugging her, he notices that she’s hot and flushed.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My child, you're burning.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: The Hummel’s are very sick. INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862. Beth, in her bed, is delirious with fever. A doctor looks over, then consults with the girls and Hannah.  83.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: She's resting.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: How is she? Is there anything I can do?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It’s scarlet fever.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What’s “scarlet fever?”

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (lowering his voice, to Mr. Laurence) I visited the Hummel’s, the baby has died.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you all had it before?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Meg and I have, but Amy hasn’t!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: She’ll have to be sent away.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be sent away!

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: I'll see if Aunt March can /I don’t like Aunt March. /take her.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: It’s for your own good, child.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Should we send for Mother?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: No, we shouldn’t worry her. I’ve never wished for money more than now.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: We’ll nurse her and she’1ll get better. You'll see. She will. She must.  84. THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869. Jo reads a story for Beth that she’s written herself, for Beth, finishing the last lines.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: “The post office in the forest was a capital little institution, and flourished wonderfully, for many things passed through it: poetry and pickles, tragedies, garden seeds and long letters, music and gingerbread, invitations, scoldings, and even puppies.” She puts down the story, looking shyly at Beth, who beams

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s all about us!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It’s just a little story.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s nothing like what you usually write.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You don’t think it’s too... boring?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No, it is my favorite one yet.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Write me another.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: And keep writing them.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I will.  85.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Even when I’m not here. It is said quickly, almost casually, but it lands like it meant to.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No, don’t say that, don’t say it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH JO
dialogues.text: I have to tell /you. /No you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I've had a very long time to think about this, and I’m not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s like the tide going out. It goes out slowly, but it can’t be stopped.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'll stop it. I’ve stopped it before. THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. LATE AT NIGHT. 1862. Jo, sitting vigil, puts cold towels on Beth’s hot forehea

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You will get better. Father will get better. And we’ll all be together soon.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: We can’t stop God’s will.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: God hasn’t met my will yet. What Jo wills shall be done. INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. Amy is working very diligently on her French and her pain - Aunt March notices the quiet little girl, and admires h

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Amy? Come here.  86.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Come, sit! Amy sits down next to Aunt March.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing to her finger) If you are very good, one day this ring will belong to you.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (marveling) Really?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: You just keep being a proper young lady and see if it doesn’t. You are your family’s hope now. Beth is sick, Jo is a lost cause, and I hear Meg has had her head turned by a penniless tutor. It’1ll be up to you to support them all, and your indigent parents in their old age. So you must marry well and save your family. Amy looks serious -- Aunt March releases her.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (breezy) That’s all I wanted to say to you. You can go finish your...little painting. Amy stands up and walks out of the one room in the past, another room in the present... THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869. ...Amy rushes in, excited, to Aunt March taking her tea:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Hello Aunt March!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: That Laurence boy was just here.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He was?  87.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: What a disappointment he’s turned out to be. It must be the Italian in him. Amy sits down without intending to.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (thrilled) When will he be back?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: He’s gone, to London. Why? What do you need to discuss with him? We briefly flash to... A country scene in the Paris exurbs. From a distance, we Fred and Amy walking. Suddenly, Fred drops to one knee, offers Amy his hand, and she drops it.... ...Back to Aunt March.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’ve just told Fred Vaughn that I wouldn't marry him. INT. MARCH HOUSE. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869. Meg is watching over Beth, who is getting weaker by the d Jo comes up with a bowl of soup, and touches Meg on the shoulder, relieving her.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Meg. Jo cocks her head towards the window, John is standing outside. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869. Meg and John are talking, tentative after their quarrel.

dialogues.speaker: MEG JOHN
dialogues.text: I’1l come home to help with /Stay. I asked for leave. the children, I’m sorry, I’m I’1l take care of the just so worried /for Beth. children.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (embracing him) John.  88.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: And there’s another thing - you should send your fabric to the dressmaker as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: MEG JOHN
dialogues.text: But I /can’t -- /No, don't say another word, I won’t hear it. I want you to have that dress. My old coat will be fine for the winter.

dialogues.speaker: MEG JOHN
dialogues.text: But /John, it’s -- It’s all settled.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: No, John, I really can’t. I sold the fabric to Sallie.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to be unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I couldn't be, John Brooke is my husband and I am his wife. Meg kisses him, spontaneously, just like years earlier. INT. MARCH HOUSE. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869. From the window, Jo watches the loving scene - feeling ha for her sister and also a pang of loneliness. Suddenly, a crash - the soup bowl clatters to the floor. Beth's fever is high and she knocked everything off the b Jo flies to her side, feeling her forehead, calling.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Hannah! THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862. Just as in the present, Beth has gotten worse.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What do we do?  89.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: We should send for your mother. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1869. Jo lays in bed with Beth. THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Marmee enters with Laurie and goes straight to Beth. She’ gone from a sick husband to a sick daughter, but she brin cheerful efficiency to a terrifying situation.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You were right to send for me, my girls - but you’ve been very good nurses indeed.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: It’s mostly been Jo, she’s hardly slept.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I didn’t know what else to do.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Hannah, go make a clear broth and Jo get ice - we need to cool her.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Who is with Father?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: John is staying with him. Meg smiles to herself, which her Mother notices.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (looking at the bed) We need to change the linens. Marmee attends to Beth while the girls help her. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. NIGHT. 1869. Meg and Jo and Marmee take turns in shifts, making sure t Beth is as comfortable as she can be. When it is Jo’s tur Beth is very weak, barely able to hold her head up.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (whispering to Beth) Don’t go quietly, fight!  90.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please fight to the end, be LOUD! Don’t just quietly go away! Jo is sitting watch, and drops off to sleep, her head on bed, her hand grasping Beth’s. Beth opens her eyes and lo down at Jo and smiles. She closes her eyes again and drif away. THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Jo jerks suddenly awake - she doesn’t see Beth in the bed She rises, and with growing panic - screams.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Marmee! Marmee! She rushes downstairs to find Beth sitting up with her Mo and Hannah eating. She cries with joy, and kisses Beth’s head.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Beth. INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. AFTEROON. 1862. It is Christmas time again. Amy, standing on a chair, supervises all the decorations. Mr. Laurence and Marmee s by the fire, and Beth on the couch with her doll. Jo runs around with Hannah setting the table for their feast. At just that moment, Laurie pops his head in and with wil excitement in his eyes, announces:

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: And here’s another Christmas gift for the March family! The door swings open, and it’s Father, supported by Mr. Brooke. Mayhem breaks out - Beth starts crying, Amy falls a chair, Marmee gasps, Jo drops a dish, and Meg (again) spontaneously kisses Mr. Brooke. All the girls run to him surrounding him in a hug.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (joyfully overwhelmed) My little women. How you've grown, and how proud I am of you. Each of you. Merry Christmas, my dears. He looks over them to Marmee - who is gazing back at him love. She wasn’t sure that this moment would come for her and she can hardly believe she has her family together. H steps out of his daughters’ hug to embrace his wife.  91.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (crying out of happiness) Thank god, thank god you’re home. Now I can be angry with you in person. He laughs, and brushes her tears away. It is romance, but real kind. LATER: It is Christmas dinner, with everyone, including t Laurences and Mr. Brooke, gathered around the table - it the finest day any one of them has ever had, and the joy radiates across the chilly Christmas night. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. MORNING. 1869. Jo jerks awake to find Beth gone - she goes downstairs an sees Marmee there. Jo looks at Marmee, and her mother, fo the first time in Jo's life, breaks. Jo becomes the paren that moment, comforting her mother, who is trapped in the unimaginable pain of losing a child. EXT. GRAVEYARD. DAY. 1869. The March family: Mother and Father and Jo, Meg and John their arms around each other, and Hannah. They have all gathered to lay their Beth to rest on an impossibly beaut day. The party walks away, each with their own pain. Jo stays, unable to leave Beth’s side, even in death. Meg makes to go approach her - but John pulls Meg closer. Meg nods - and she is grateful to him, grateful that she married this man who can be there for her. Jo cries, alone. She cannot comprehend how the world keep spinning when her Beth is gone. We go from the emptiness the grief to... THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865. .+-a beautiful day, full of flowers and sunlight. Outside Beth and Amy are arranging decorations and laughing. Inside, Meg prepares for her wedding with Jo helping her, placing flowers in her sister’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I can’t believe today is my wedding day!  92.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (sadly) Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JO...
dialogues.text: Jo suddenly kneels before her, wild and desperate: But, Jo..

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: We can leave. We can leave right now.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I can make money: I’1l1 sell stories, I'll do anything - cook, clean, work in a factory. I can make a life for us.

dialogues.speaker: MEG JO
dialogues.text: And you, you should be an actress and have a life on the stage. Let’s run away together.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I want to get married.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I love him.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (angry) You will be bored of him in two years and we will be interesting forever.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Just because my dreams are not the same as yours doesn’t mean they’re unimportant.  93. Jo sits back, heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: MEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want a family and a home and I’m not scared of working and struggling, but I want to do it with John.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I just hate that you’re leaving me.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Oh, Jo, I’m not leaving you. Besides, one day it will be your turn.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'd rather be a free spinster and paddle my own canoe. (hugging her, crying) I can’t believe childhood is over.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: It was going to end one way or another. And what a happy end. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865. Meg and Mr. Brooke are married, with Mr. March officiatin

dialogues.speaker: MR.MARCH
dialogues.text: What excessive promises, giving yourself away to get the other. What a thing, what a gift, always given before it is known the cost or the reward. During the simple and emotional ceremony, Amy and Jo catc each others eye - they simultaneously realize that they a the only two left standing. Later, during the picnic reception: - Marmee and Hannah deliver cakes and pastries and food galore. - Laurie dances with Beth, whirling her around, and makin her laugh. Jo watches adoringly: the two halves of her he - Meg, both bride and host, makes sure everyone is cared - Laurie and Jo taste the alcohol and decide it’s terribl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Meg dances with John, Marmee dances with Mr. Laurence, tries to play the fiddle - then Marmee dances with Father and Meg dance, John and Amy dance, Hannah dances with Fat The point is, everyone dances with everyone and... - Mr. Laurence offers to dance with Aunt March, but she t him down. Then Laurie also approaches her. Aunt March fei even MORE hatred, to cover her epic delight. - There is more eating and dancing until the sun starts t set. As Aunt March moves to make her departure, she speak Meg, who stands with John, Marmee and Father March.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you’re happy. Now that you've ruined your life, just like your Mother did by marrying your father. Despite her meanness, the March family is so happy, that burst out laughing at Aunt March’s rudeness.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Dear Sister, you are too kind. And thank you for today’s festivities.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: You are most welcome.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (leaning in to kiss her) Thank you Aunt March.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, I don’t like to be...

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: (back at Meg) You'll be sorry when you've tried love in a cottage and found it a failure!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (smiling sweetly) It can’t be worse than some people find in big houses.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: I understood your meaning, my dear.  95. Meg and John retreat and laugh and kiss. Nothing can pier their happiness.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Marmee) I don’t miss a THING.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: (taking Aunt March’s arm and leading her away) You are not entirely wrong.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH
dialogues.text: I may not always be right, but I am NEVER wrong. Amy takes over from Marmee, Aunt March gratefully accepti her hand.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank goodness, here’s the only sane member of the family. I really can’t take any more of this. Amy leads her away, and Marmee lets them go. Amy gets Aun March into a carriage and then lets out a cry of joy. She runs to Marmee, who is now standing with Jo:

dialogues.speaker: AMY JO
dialogues.text: Marmee! Marmee! Aunt March is /wants me to go with her! H going to Europe /and wonderful! Now I know why I spent all those BORING hours reading to her! Jo throws her arms around Amy, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No, she... she wanted me to come. As her companion.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (stunned) Europe? With you?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: She wants me to work on my art, and my French, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh... I, that’s wonderful Amy. Marmee takes Jo’s hand, knowing how this hurt her. Jo smi through her pain for Meg’s day, but it is a true blow.  96. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. DAY. 1865. John and Meg enter their small but lovely newlywed home. embraces her and kisses her - she’s never been happier. EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866. Laurie and Jo walk through the woods together, as they've done for years.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Meg married, Amy off to Europe, now that you’re a graduate, you’1ll be off on a long holiday - I’m not good like Beth so I’m angry and restless.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Why? Should we run off and join a pirate ship? He looks at her, and inhales, about to talk. Jo sees his and immediately knows what is about to happen. No, no,

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (panicking) No, Teddy -- please don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: It’s no use Jo; we’ve got to have it out..

dialogues.speaker: JO LAURIE
dialogues.text: /we don't... I’ve loved you ever since I’ve known you Jo -- I couldn’t help it, and you’ve been so good to me -- I’ve tried to show it but you wouldn’t let me; now I’m going to make you hear and give me an answer because I can’t go on like this any longer.  97.

dialogues.speaker: JO LAURIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to save you from (not listening to her) this, I thought /you’d /I've worked hard to please understand. you, and I gave up billiards and everything you didn’t like, and waited and never complained for I hoped you'd love me, though I’m not half good enough --

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes, you are, you’re a great deal too good for me, and I’m so grateful to you and so proud of you, I don’t see why I... I can’t love you as you want me to.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You can’t?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (helplessly) I can’t change the feeling and it would be a lie to say I do when I don’t. I’m so sorry, Teddy, so desperately sorry, but I can’t help it... Laurie backs away from her like she hit him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I can’t love any one else.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It would be a disaster if we married, we'd be miserable! We both have such quick tempers --

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: -- If you loved me Jo, I would be a perfect saint!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I can’t - I’ve tried it and failed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Everyone expects it -- Grandpa and your family, Jo say you will and let’s be happy!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I can’t say “Yes” truly so I won’t say it at all.  98.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll see that I’m right, eventually, and you’1ll thank me for it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I‘1l be hanged if I do!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You'll find some lovely accomplished girl, who will adore you, and make a fine mistress for your fine house. I wouldn’t. I’m homely and awkward and odd and you'd be ashamed of me and we would quarrel - we can’t help it even now! - I’d hate elegant society and you'd hate my scribbling and we would be unhappy and wish we hadn’t done it and everything will be horrid.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Anything more?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Nothing more -- except that... (honest) I don’t believe I will ever marry. I’m happy as I am, and love my liberty too well to be in any hurry to give it up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) You will care for somebody, and you'll love him tremendously, and live and die for him. I know you will, it’s your way, and you will and I’1ll watch.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Teddy. . He straightens up and walks away. Jo cries and cries. Her heart is breaking, even though she is the one who broke i THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869. Jo is putting away Beth’s things, and arranging her littl dolls and toys. Everyone is gone. Meg left by marriage, A left by a voyage to Europe, Laurie left because she rejec him and Beth was taken from this life. She places sheet m of Beth’s into a trunk, the hurt in her heart almost unbearable.  99.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I hope I’m not disturbing your writing...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I don’t do that anymore. (then) It didn’t save her. They sit beside each other, both missing Beth.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You are much too lonely here, Jo. Wouldn't you like to go back to New York? What about your friend - Friedrich, was that his name?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (resigned) I ruined our friendship with my temper, just as I ruin everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: I doubt a sincere friend would be deterred.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I wish that were true. If I were a girl in a book, this would all be so easy, I’d give up the world happily.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Laurie is returning, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (looking up) He is?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: There was a letter from Amy, she’s coming home: She was devastated about Beth and Aunt March is very ill - but Laurie will be accompanying them on the journey home.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (nodding) That’s good of him. Jo stands and paces, anxiously.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Perhaps... perhaps I was too quick in turning him down.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: If he asked me again, I think I would say yes... Do you think he’1l ask me again?

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: But do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (tearing up) I know that I care more to be loved. I want to be loved.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: That is not the same as loving.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (crying, trying to explain herself to herself) Women have minds and souls as well as hearts, ambition and talent as well as beauty and I’m sick of being told that love is all a woman is fit for. But... I am so lonely. EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869. Amy, dressed in black, is waiting with all her luggage - is in mourning. A carriage approaches and Laurie gets out tentatively walks to Amy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t let you travel alone with Aunt March being so sick - even if you despise me.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, Laurie, I don’t despise you. She embraces him, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beth was the best of us.  101. Laurie is quiet, letting her cry. She pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’m not marrying Fred Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (carefully) I heard... Amy...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (rush of words) It was not for you it was for myself. You are under no obligation to say anything or do anything, it was because I didn’t love him as I should. Laurie studies her face, and we know that he sees her and loves her.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (still rambling) You don’t have to say anything, we never need to talk about it, we don’t have to talk about -- Laurie catches her face with his hands, and kisses her. S looks at him and kisses him back. They embrace with both their joy and their grief. This is the way it was meant. is done. INT. MARCH HOUSE ATTIC. DAY. 1869. Jo infused with a new kind of energy, writes to Laurie. W hear snippets of the letter.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My dear Teddy, I miss you more than I can express. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. In the forest, Jo finds the mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...I used to think the worst fate was to be a wife, I was young and stupid. Now I have changed. The worst fate is to live my life without you in it. I was wrong to turn you down and to run away to New York.  102. She opens it and places the letter inside, she looks at i satisfied. She closes the mailbox back up again. THE PAST. EXT. STREETS OF NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1867. Jo tries to find her way through the unfamiliar city - sh isn’t an expert at it quite yet. She walks too slowly, st too long, and gets hopelessly lost - but a spark of happi is growing, she’s figuring out how to be what Aunt March was impossible - a woman making her own way in the world. She walks up the stairs to the boarding house and as she ascends the stairs and the doors open, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 186
dialogues.text: Jo, asleep on the couch, is gently shaken awake. She sees

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Jo? Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh Teddy! My Teddy!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Dear Jo, are you glad to see me then? Jo embraces him and looks at him and holds him for too lo

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Glad, my blessed boy, is too small! Words can’t express it. Laurie breaks their embrace.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Oh thank heaven, I was worried, well, anyway, I wanted a moment with you alone.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Here, come sit. They take a moment, not sure what to do. They aren’t in t youth any longer, they aren’t sure how to relate to each other.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (making a joke) How's Amy?  103.

dialogues.speaker: JO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did she bother you all the way from Europe with her preening?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Yes, but I love it.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Where is she now? Did she not come straight home?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Your mother’s got her down at Meg's, we stopped there by the way, and there was no getting my wife out of their clutches.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Your... your what?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Now I’ve done it! It was meant to be a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What surprise?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Well, we were engaged, and we were going to wait... that is to say, now we are man and wife. Jo sits. She’s hit hard.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You and... Amy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: It all happened very fast.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Are you - in love?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Yes. (launching in) Jo, I want to say one thing, and then we’ll put it away forever. I have always loved you; but the love I feel for Amy is different - you were right - we would have killed each other.  104.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (still in shock) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I think it was meant this way.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh, Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No one ever calls me that but you.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What does Amy call you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: My Lord.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: That’s like her... Well, you look deserving of it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Can we - can we still be friends? Though it takes a supreme effort, she says:

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Of course, my boy, always. At that moment, everyone comes bursting through the door. Mother and Father and Amy and John and Meg and Daisy and - Amy goes straight to Jo. Jo fixes her face and decides will be the person she wishes she was:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Laurie told you?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes. Amy looks at her expectantly. Jo has a moment of wanting strike her, the way she did when they were children, but checks herself, and tries to be what Beth would want:

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Amy, I’m so happy for you. It was meant to be. Amy sighs, her anxiety lifts:  105.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m so relieved - I couldn't write because it all happened so quickly and then, really, I was worried you'd be angry.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No, no.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: So you aren’t? Angry?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Life is too short to be angry at one’s sisters.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (tearing up) I really miss her...

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I know. They embrace. Over her shoulder she catches her mother’s who gives her a look of infinite empathy. Then Laurie calls for his wife. Jo straightens up and see these couples - Mother & Father, John & Meg, Laurie & Amy It all hits her with a heat and a mass that she was unprepared for. She hastily excuses herself and goes outs EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. Weeping, but also in a panic, Jo removes the letter from mailbox and walks into the woods. EXT. WOODS. DAY. 1869. She tears through the woods and finally stands by the riv breathing heavily. For one moment, we believe that she mi end her suffering in the most tragic way - she leans towa the river... .--and throws the letter into it, letting it drift away, along with her childhood love. It is over. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. Jo trudges back, and is surprised to find Mr. Laurence standing alone, looking at the March’s house.  106.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Mr. Laurence?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Jo! They embrace - and then Mr. Laurence tries to explain:

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: I couldn't bring myself to... The house doesn’t seem right without her and I couldn’t go in knowing she wouldn’t be there. He begins crying. Jo takes his arm tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I know I am not half so good as my sister, but I'll be a friend to lean on, if you’1l let me. He gratefully accepts her help and they approach the hous together, an odd, sweet pair of friends. INT. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM/ATTIC. NIGHT/DAY. 1869. Jo starts awake - she looks around the room: she’s all al everyone is truly gone. She lights a candle. She goes to drawer where she keeps her writing, and pulls out the sta She feeds a published story into the fire. Then she burns more stories, printed, unpublished, half-finished, she bu them all. It is a potlatch, a total burning down of everything she has made up until this point. She finds one last piece, and is about to give it over to fire, when she reads on top: “For Beth.” She stops. Jo makes her way up to the attic, and sits in her old wri chair, looking at the story. She takes a fresh sheet of p and starts writing. She writes all night, and into the next day, piling up pa after page. She spreads them out in the attic, like a qui building outwards. Candles are lit and re-lit, the sun ri and sets. Marmee brings her some food and then leaves her alone. Jo nods off for a second then keeps writing. She revises, scratches out, she changes orders. She falls asleep on he blanket of papers.  107. She's re-connected with her childhood, and out of the dep of despair has found hope and inspiration. Jo finishes and carefully ties up the first few chapters this experiment and writes a letter to Mr. Dashwood:

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (read to camera) Dear Mr. Dashwood: Enclosed are the first few chapters of a piece I’ve only begun working on. It could suit as a story for young people, but I think it is probably quite boring. However, I’m sending it to you just in case it has something of value, though I doubt it. INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869. The empty rooms of Aunt March’s house -- nothing is left the deliciously cranky old lady. Furniture is covered ove and the loss is felt in the grand rooms. Amy, Jo and Meg around the big empty mansion.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I thought she hated me.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: She could still hate you and leave you the house! Jo laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What about you and John?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: No, I don’t need a grand estate. Meg looks satisfied, and we know that she is, deeply. Suddenly, Jo lets out a WHOOP and runs through the house.

dialogues.speaker: MEG AMY
dialogues.text: For heaven's /sake! /What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (looking around) I should sell it, but I’d love to do something that would really make Aunt March turn in her grave.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind that.  108.

dialogues.speaker: AMY JO
dialogues.text: /Girls! /A nice turning, just a rotation, nothing terrible.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: What will you do? Jo thinks for half a second, but she already knows:

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I'd like to open a school. We never had a proper school, and now there are women’s colleges opening - there should be a school. For Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: And what will Demi do?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I’1l open a school for boys and girls, both. Amy takes her sister’s arm on one side, while Meg is on t other side. They walk and talk confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What about writing?

dialogues.speaker: JO MEG
dialogues.text: (Jo turns bright red) What are you working on? What /about it?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I started something... but I don’t think it’s very good.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Everyone likes what you write.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (pointedly) No, they don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It’s just about our little life.  109.

dialogues.speaker: AMY JO
dialogues.text: So? Who will be interested ina story of domestic struggles and joys? It doesn’t have any real importance.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Maybe we don’t see those things as important because people don’t write about them.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No, writing doesn’t confer importance, it reflects it.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. Perhaps writing will make them more important.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (looking at her, amused) When did you become so wise?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I always have been, you were just too busy noticing my faults.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Which weren’t there, of course. They lean their heads together and stroll through the hou INT. NEW YORK PUBLISHING OFFICE. DAY. 1869. Mr. Dashwood sits, reading the pages that Jo gave him. He finishes and then writes to her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: (read to camera) Dear Miss March: I have read the chapters you sent, and I have to agree that they aren’t very promising. But, please send us more stories of the scandalous variety, if you have any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo reads the note Mr. Dashwood sent:

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or, shall I say, your friend can. My apologies for the joke, I couldn't help it.  110. And she crumples it up. Just then, Marmee breaks her reve

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jo! Come down!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Coming! I’m starving! Jo stashes her writing and clomps down the stairs and hea straight for the table, not even looking around her. She down and grabs a piece of bread and takes a big bite.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Jo, you might want to wait..

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: But I’m famished.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: Jo, dear, you have a guest.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I don’t know anyone.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I am so sorry to intrude. Jo hears his voice and bolts up.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (she bursts out laughing) It’s you! THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867. Jo, with all of her luggage, finds the address and rings doorbell. Friedrich opens it, he smiles down at this youn woman, with his handsome face and merry eyes -- she comes undone before even knowing it.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Hello. I’m Josephine March. Jo. Just then, Mrs. Kirke pushes past him, with her two child

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRKE
dialogues.text: (to be delivered without stopping for breath, with infinite cheer and anxiety) Jo! Is that you?! Come in, come in!  111.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your mother says that you’re a writer — how wonderful! I keep a diary, you know. This is Kitty and Minny. SMILE GIRLS. I see you’ve met our professor, he’s a very accomplished man, actually, it’s an interesting group here, lots of intellectuals and Europeans. You know I never thought I’d run a boarding house but here I am! How is that sweet mother of yours? She always had such great height, I never had that, she could reach anything... She leads Jo up through the stairs and Jo takes a quick glance backwards at Friedrich, as if to confirm that the she saw was real and not an apparition. She finds Friedri looking back up at her. She turns away again. BACK TO THE PRESENT. 1869.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: Jo, I hope it is all right, I got your address from Mrs. Kirke -

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Who are you? (to Amy) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: (backing away) I’m so sorry to intrude, I was close by and thought I’d, but I’1l be going...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: - Please stay! We have more than enough room.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Can someone tell me who he is!?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be a burden.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: It’s no burden at all.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (still stunned) Yes, of course. Please.  112.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (proprietary) I’m Laurie. And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: I am Friedrich Bhaer.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (explaining) We were at the same boarding house together in New York.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Oh JO, he’s VERY handsome. Later: Everyone is talking. Father and Friedrich especially talk philosophy and religion and politics. Father obviously ve much likes him. Jo is glowing with happiness. Amy looks from Friedrich to Jo and from Jo to Friedrich. can see that there is love between them.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (to Friedrich) And you intend to stay in New York?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: No, I’ve been offered a professorship in California - and as I have nothing keeping me here, I thought I might go West. It is new there, and they are less particular about immigrants. Jo has an unconscious sharp intake of breath. No one noti but Amy. Father continues oblivious:

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should go West...

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: You aren’t an immigrant, so perhaps you should stay home. Everyone bursts out laughing. Father laughs at himself go naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m going.  113. INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869. Everyone relaxes after dinner, and Friedrich eyes the pia

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: This is a beautiful instrument. Which one of you plays? They all fall quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It was my sister, Beth.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: We all play a little.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: But none so well as her...

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: It is very hard to lose a sister. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Do you play?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: I do, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARMEE
dialogues.text: It would make us so happy if you played now, she wouldn’t want the piano to sit silent.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: I don’t wish to offend.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Not in the least. He sits down and plays Bach - it is beautiful and elegant watches him, moved and deeply happy. The sound of his music plays over Friedrich saying his goodbyes and telling Jo, as he stands at the door:

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: Jo, if you ever come to California, I would love to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I don’t know that I will, but thank you.  114.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: (hurting, but accepting) Well, yes... goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Goodbye. It has started to rain, and he puts up his umbrella and trudges into the evening. The door closes. Jo turns back around to find everyone staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What?! Why are you all looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: What a wonderful man. I hope he comes again, he would be a terrific friend for me.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (crying out) Oh Father, he wasn’t here for you!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Jo! You love him!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I do not!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You do too! I may be half as smart as you are but I can see it so plainly, you love him. I have never seen you happier. What else is love? Doesn’t she love him Mr. Laurence?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: That’s a good instinct, you love him.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Go get him. Laurie prepare the horses. We can catch him before he gets to the train.  115.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (standing) I’m coming too.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I’m not going!

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: You are. Amy is right.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I never thought I’d prepare a carriage to help Jo March go after aman, but I like it.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: He’s moving to California!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: That’s a fiction. He was practically begging for a reason to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: But it’s raining outside.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter! Put on a better dress. Follow me. Amy has started ascending the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (jumping to action) Yes, my love. INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869. It is also raining in New York. Mr. Dashwood is in his co apartment, eating dinner with his wife. She tries to star fight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: You never ask about my mother even when you know I’ve seen her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: I assume she’s still alive.  116.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: But I ask after your mother.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: And I have no idea why.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: You're willfully missing the point.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: That’s true. He hears his daughter’s laughter and talking in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: What have they gotten into now?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: I have no idea. The girls tumble into the room, speaking over each other.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD GIRL
dialogues.text: Father are you publishing/ /What happens to the Little this? Women?

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD GIRL
dialogues.text: Tell me you have the rest of the book! Close on Mr. Dashwood as he realizes what he has, what th story could be, this story that he, and the author, both thought was boring... INT/EXT. CARRIAGE./TRAIN STATION. NIGHT. 1869. Meg, Amy, and Jo are all in the carriage, making top spee through the rain. They arrive at the train station.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: GO! Find him! Jo runs in the rain towards the beautifully lit station a the music swells and the thunder claps and we CUT TO: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870. Jo sits where she originally sat across from Dashwood, bu now she is more grown up, more together, more herself -

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Frankly, I don’t see why she didn’t marry the neighbor.  Jo thinks. Jo shifts. 117.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Because the neighbor married her sister!

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Right, of course. So, who does she marry?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No one. She doesn’t marry either of them.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: No. No, no, no, that won’t work at all.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: She says the whole book that she doesn’t want to marry.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: WHO CARES! Girls want to see women MARRIED. Not CONSISTENT.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It isn’t the right ending.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: The right ending is the one that sells. Dashwood pounces.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you end your delightful book with your heroine a spinster, no one will buy it. It won’t be worth printing. She considers.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I suppose marriage has always been an economic proposition. Even in fiction.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: It’s romance!

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: It’s mercenary.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Just end it that way, will you?  118.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING. 1869.
dialogues.text: Jo runs from the carriage, out into the rain and into the crowd in front of the train station, looking for Friedric He’s not there, every face isn’t his. Couple after couple stands under umbrellas. She runs into the station, and th turns around to go back out -- has she missed him? Just then:

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: Jo! Jo sees Friedrich, also standing under an umbrella, but alone. She runs towards him. She feels her emotions risin she starts to cry, despite herself.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jo, why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Because -- because you are going away.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: I would never leave if you wished me to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I wish you would stay.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH
dialogues.text: But, but I have nothing to give you but my full heart and these empty hands.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (she puts her hands in his, and steps under the umbrella) They aren’t empty now. They kiss one of those epic perfect kisses. The train arrives, and he doesn’t get on it. BAM.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1
dialogues.text: Back to negotiations.  119.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I love it. It’s so romantic. “Your hands aren’t empty now.” It makes me emotional. He gets a little teary.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: We can call the chapter “Under the Umbrella.”

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: (has to admit) It’s good.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Perfect! Now there is the question of the contract... I’m prepared to give you 5% of the royalties.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: So I get 5% of the profit?

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: 5% of the net profits. After I re- coup.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What about a payment, upfront?

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I’m taking the risk in printing this book.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Yes, but, but it’s my book.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: If it works, then we’1ll both make money. If not, then I won’t go under.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: So I get nothing? If it fails?

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: No, I‘’1l give you $500 dollars right now to buy out the copyright.  120.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: The copyright?

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: It’s the right for re-printing, that sort of thing, sequels, the characters for other stories.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Might that be worth something?

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Well, again, only if it’s a success.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I see. It seems like something I would want to own.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Doesn't your family need the money more immediately?

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: They do, which is why I wanted upfront payment.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: I‘1l only pay for the copyright. An intense moment between them. Her book hangs in the balance. She leans forward, resolute.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You keep your $500, and I’1l keep the copyright, thank you. Also, I want ten percent of royalties.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Five point five percent and that is very generous.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Nine percent.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Six percent -- and that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: If I’m going to sell my heroine into marriage for money, I might as well get some of it.  121.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: Six point six percent.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: DASHWOOD
dialogues.text: And you don’t need to decide about the copyright now.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: I've decided. I want to own my own book. We fade down on this scene, and fade up on: FICTION(?) INT./EXT. PLUMFIELD ACADEMY. DAY. 1871. Jo is supervising a great number of rambunctious girls an boys of all races and ages. They are finishing lessons fo the day, and everyone runs outside at full speed. Jo makes her way down the stairs and is handed a homemade cake by one of the children. She kisses him on the head a continues through what she’s built. Every inch of the sch is covered with the students’ work, all of the former stuffiness is gone. She’s in her heaven. INT. PRINTING HOUSE. DAY. 1871. Jo, captivated, watches type being set, each letter put i place, and one page after another pressed with her novel. FICTION(?) INT./EXT. PLUMFIELD ACADEMY. DAY. 1871. Jo walks past Friedrich’s classroom, all the students wit their violins learning from him how to play. They smile a each other and she continues out. INT. PRINTING HOUSE. DAY. 1871. Each page is stacked one on top of the other and the mass industrial sewing machine stitches the pages together as observes. FICTION(?) EXT. PLUMFIELD ACADEMY. DAY. 1871. Jo walks past Laurie giving a fencing lesson (while also holding his baby), Amy conducting a painting lesson, Meg supervising children in a play rehearsal, John Brooke (hi own children next to him) leading a botany lesson... they join Jo as she troupes down the lawn.  122. INT. PRINTING HOUSE. DAY. 1871. The excesses of each page are sliced off, making a satisf sound, and making Jo jump and laugh at her jumpiness. FICTION(?) EXT. PLUMFIELD ACADEMY. DAY. 1871. Leading a procession of children and family behind her, a holding the cake, Jo and the group arrive upon Father, teaching the very young children the alphabet by having t bodies form the letters, and also Marmee, who is having e child read aloud in their best dramatic reading voice. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. DAY. 1871. The hard cover of the book is placed over the pages, the to hold it in place is so strong-smelling as to make Jo dizzy. FICTION(?) EXT. PLUMFIELD ACADEMY. DAY. 1871. Jo presents her mother with the cake, and all of them, Am Meg, Jo, Laurie, John, Friedrich, Father, and the childre wish her a happy birthday. Jo looks around at the group, happy she was able to be alive with them, so amazed. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. DAY. 1871. A man finishes the book, and unceremoniously hands it to and gets to work on the next one. THE PAST, OR MAYBE FICTION, OR MAYBE BOTH. 1850S. Beth, Meg, Amy and Jo are very young girls, playing in th attic, together again, if only in memory, or in the book. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. DAY. 1871. Jo turns it over in her hands, touching it like the holy object it is, her inchoate desire made manifest. Jo looks up ... and sees the future - CUT TO BLACK. Credits.
